Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2009 10:36PM LindaYO wrote: Amiekae, Your courage is already showing by sharing your story.  You will learn as you go--hour by hour, day by day.  Some days will be harder than others.  You WILL make it.  Hang in there.  This forum is full of survivors!!  And combined, we have been there, done that, and can offer you support whenever you want it. God bless you and yours.  You and your family will be in my prayers. L:)
Posts.Title: 31 and just diagnosed amiekae Jodi_Smart

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2009 01:15AM LindaYO wrote: Snowflake & Brian,   Good luck as you proceed through chemo.  Your side effects may be minimal; make sure you communicate with doctors if they are bothersome.  There are many meds they can give you to counteract.  Also, you are being proactive in researching your treatment, and that is SOOOO critical.  Knowledge is power.  There is so much information available to us including non-prescribed therapies. Keep going strong!! And keep thinking positively!  I know that is so important.   Lots of cyber hugs are coming your way!! God bless. L:)
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed - what should we look for in a doctor? Snowflake70 LindaYO

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2009 10:53PM LindaYO wrote: Brian & Snowflake,   Many prayers are being sent on your behalf.  I know you are getting a lot of good advice and support.  My best advice is to educate yourself every step of the way.  The internet is such a blessing for gathering information.  Then you can ask questions of your docs and be sure you are getting the best treatment for your diagnosis.     I switched oncologists when my cancer returned  a year after intial diagnosis; he talked about quality of life and keeping me comfortable.  I immediately found another who believes  that possibilities for successful treatment are endless.  We have been "together" as a fighting team for 11 years now. You are such a blessing to each other.  God bless you! L:)
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed - what should we look for in a doctor? Snowflake70 LindaYO

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2009 07:40PM - edited Apr 20, 2009 07:41PM by LindaYO Just got off the phone with my onc about the se's that are wreaking havoc on my body.  Just had 3rd treatment of Gemzar on Friday and still not off the couch.  He said the se's won't get any better.  So he's suggesed navelbine, but he did not mention neuropathy.  I quit Taxol after 13months due to numbness in feet. So I'm a bit apprehensive about the switch. HOpefully it won't be an issue.  I am tired of feeling tired of sick 3 days out of each week:)  It can get better, right? L:)

Posts.Content: May 16, 2009 02:49PM LindaYO wrote: Vicki,   YIPPPPEEEEE for YOU!!!  We are so happy for you Saying prayers for continued good results.  God Bless You.

Posts.Content: May 4, 2009 11:18PM LindaYO wrote: Princess, Keep us abreast of what's going on, detail by detail.  Then we can give you help and advice.  Good luck, girl.  Maybe you'll sail right through! L:)
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo May 2008 KristyAnn Nico1012

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2009 02:19AM LindaYO wrote: Lost my hair again 13 months ago when I started Taxol.  Because of neuropathy, onc has switched my treatment to Gemzar; he says I might get my hair back. Now I'm not sure I WANT it to grow back.  I love being able to go natural (bald) most of the time or adding a wig when I feel like it.  Additionally, it seems people are friendlier and kinder when they see the bald head.  I may keep it off for good!!

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2009 08:08PM LindaYO wrote: Gemzar treatment 3 tomorrow.  I've felt crappy all week; not looking forward to another treatment.  I'm having se's that I didn't have with Taxol.  I HATE IT!!!  Sorry for the pity party:(
Posts.Title: Gemzar anyone? vivo LindaYO

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2009 07:13AM LindaYO wrote: I received my first Gemzar treatment on Friday.  I'll also get Zometa monthly.  Nurse said 3 days out would tell the store of any se's I will have.  So far only se is from the dexamethazone they infused just before the chemo.  I sure hope this works for a long time.
Posts.Title: Gemzar anyone? vivo LindaYO

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2009 01:57PM LindaYO wrote: Lilac,   I'm glad you plan to talk to your onc.  I have been Stage IV for 11 years with mets in the bones.  I have been on 8 different meds--some chemo, some hormonal.  There are many options out there for you!   Your oncologist's role is to provide you with the best options there are FOR YOU!!  If he/she doesn't do that, there  many who will. Sending hugs and prayers your way.  Hang in there!!
Posts.Title: Thinking about quiting chemo Lilac Godsgal

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2009 01:50PM LindaYO wrote: I just had my second dose of Gemzar yesterday.  No headache or nausea.  Really no se's.  My plateIets were good but white cells down.  But not low enough to modify dosage.  Next week will tell the tale of how my white count bounces back--or not.  I have been on Taxol for the past 13 months, so hair has been growing back for at least the last 6months, but splotchy and thin.  So I just keep it buzzed..  I'm having trouble finding information about success rates with Gemzar.  I hope it works for a long time for all of us!!
Posts.Title: Gemzar janmarie LindaYO

Posts.Content: May 23, 2009 05:14AM LindaYO wrote: I've been on chemo since April of 08.  So I've been bald for most of that time.  I had a couple of wigs from my first treatments 11 years ago.  Bought a couple of really fun, sexy wigs that I tried on in Florida when I visited my brothers early last fall.  I LOVE being bald.  I never have looked good in a baseball cap.  And wigs can get pretty uncomfortable, especially during hotflashes.  So I mostly go bald, sometimes with body glitter on my head.  When I have the urge for hair, I pick the one that fits the mood and the outfit.  And when I need to keep warm, a wig helps.  Love having the freedom to choose what I want to look like.  I, too, have had so many positive experiences with the bald head.  Smiles and kindness abound.  Compliments, too.  I think many people count their blessings after they see me.  They don't know that I count my blessings, too!!     Bald IS beautiful!  And so are we!!  Apple, I LOVE the scarf look.  I may try that this summer!
Posts.Title: Embracing the Bald BooBee Meadow
